journalEntries.title: Here goes nothing!!
journalEntries.content: This could be my first-ever journal entry transmitted over a network.

journalEntries.title: OK... Third time's a charm...
journalEntries.content: Here's my third attempt at pushing a journal entry to the server.

journalEntries.title: Let's fuck something up here
journalEntries.content:
The first of those examples will reference the first instance of a UL node in the ordered_list class. The second example will reference - prepare yourself - the first LI element within the first UL element within the first LI element within the UL element with the ID contact_phone_numbers that also contains a UL that contains a LI. Here's how that looks in code:

    // here's our starting point

  • 1
    • // doesn't contain a UL, so no go

  • // contains a UL and a LI, so this is it!

    • 2
      • // our target!

  • 3

The cool thing about this is that there are no class names or IDs this deep into a list, but we can still search for it in reference to its proximity to its nearest labeled node.

Lastly on searching (selecting) shit in the DOM, there's also a document.querySelectorAll method that will return a node list like the document.getElement(s) methods.

Once you've found your DOM element, you can do work on it with JS by modifying its innterText, textContent, or innerHTML properties. the innerText property represents all text within the node that is visible (not hidden) to the user of the website. textContent represents ALL text - even hidden stuff. innerHTML is the real game changer in that it allows you to replace the HTML within a node. Sometimes that might just be the text that appears onscreen. Other times, it may be an entire screen element. This one takes savvy so as not to mess shit up. And, if the HTML is being changed based on user input, it's best to limit it to hard-coded values that are selectable rather than allowing the user to submit their own change. A savvy user might realize that they could pass HTML code as their submission and mess up a site.

At the highest level, when interacting with servers, our "requests" will take the form of one of the maiin HTTP verbs: GET, POST, PATCH/PUT, or DELETE. We sometimes see the acronym CRUD as a mnemonic for these verbs. IT stands for CREATE (POST), READ (GET), UPDATE (PATCH/PUT), DESTROY (DELETE).

All HTTP verba:

GET Retrieves a representation of a resource

POST Create a new resource using data in the content of the request

PUT Update an existing resource using data in the content of the request

PATCH Update part of an existing resource using data in the content of the request

DELETE Deletes a specific resource

HEAD Asks for a response (like a GET but without the content)

TRACE Echoes back the received request

OPTIONS Returns the HTTP methods the server supports

CONNECT Converts the request to a TCP/IP tunnel (generally for SSL)

journalEntries.title: This shouldn't allow blanks
journalEntries.content:
This shouldn't allow poor formatting

In the following function, you can see that I have elements representing the entry title and entry datestamp, and entry content, as well as entry header and entry. The entry title and datestamp always go into the entry header. The entry header and content always go into the entry. This is a structure that will be built every time someone inputs text on my website. Is there a way to leverage object classes to create a class that would build a new instance of this entire structure, and populate it with the data passed to it so that I don't have to run this entire function every time the submit button is pressed?

function renderJournalEntry(entryObj) {

let entry = document.createElement('div');

entry.className = 'journal_entry';

let entryHeader = document.createElement('div');

entryHeader.className = "entry_header";

let entryTitle = document.createElement('h2');

entryTitle.className = 'entry_title';

entryTitle.innerText = entryObj.title;

let entryDatestamp = document.createElement('p');

entryDatestamp.className = 'entry_datestamp';

entryDatestamp.innerText = entryObj.entryDate;

let entryContent = document.createElement('div');

entryContent.className = "entry_content";

entryContent.innerHTML = entryObj.entry;

entryHeader.appendChild(entryTitle);

entryHeader.appendChild(entryDatestamp);

entry.appendChild(entryHeader);

entry.appendChild(entryContent);

ChatGPT

Yes, you can leverage object-oriented programming in JavaScript to create a class that represents your journal entry structure. Here's how you can create such a class:

javascript

Copy code

class JournalEntry {

constructor(entryObj) {

this.entry = document.createElement('div');

this.entry.className = 'journal_entry';

this.entryHeader = document.createElement('div');

this.entryHeader.className = 'entry_header';

this.entryTitle = document.createElement('h2');

this.entryTitle.className = 'entry_title';

this.entryTitle.innerText = entryObj.title;

this.entryDatestamp = document.createElement('p');

this.entryDatestamp.className = 'entry_datestamp';

this.entryDatestamp.innerText = entryObj.entryDate;

this.entryContent = document.createElement('div');

this.entryContent.className = 'entry_content';

this.entryContent.innerHTML = entryObj.entry;

this.entryHeader.appendChild(this.entryTitle);

this.entryHeader.appendChild(this.entryDatestamp);

this.entry.appendChild(this.entryHeader);

this.entry.appendChild(this.entryContent);

}

render() {

return this.entry;

}

}
